question.title: Determine which camera used by Android camera activity

node.contents: I'm writing an Android app that relies upon a user periodically taking pictures. It has been documented that Android will return an image flipped and rotated at 90 degrees if a picture was taken from the front-facing camera. I am able to successfully reorient the picture when this happens. The problem is that I don't know how to tell when the front-facing camera is used. By knowing when the front-facing camera was used while taking a picture, I can determine whether I should be re-orienting it or not.

astNode.text: I'm writing an Android app that relies upon a user periodically taking pictures. It has been documented that Android will return an image flipped and rotated at 90 degrees if a picture was taken from the front-facing camera. I am able to successfully reorient the picture when this happens. The problem is that I don't know how to tell when the front-facing camera is used. By knowing when the front-facing camera was used while taking a picture, I can determine whether I should be re-orienting it or not.

node.contents: Is there any way to determine, preferably during onActivityResult(), which camera was used? Is there another practice used to help determine and fix picture orientation?

astNode.text: Is there any way to determine, preferably during onActivityResult(), which camera was used? Is there another practice used to help determine and fix picture orientation?

node.contents: Here is my Camera activity launch code. Very straight forward:

astNode.text: Here is my Camera activity launch code. Very straight forward:

elements.contents: private void startCameraIntent(String name) { try { String fileName = MontageConstants.APP_DATA_FOLDER + "/" + name + "/" + new Date().getTime() + ".jpg"; Uri fileUri = Uri.fromFile(new File(fileName)); Intent takePictureIntent = new Intent(MediaStore.ACTION_IMAGE_CAPTURE); takePictureIntent.putExtra(MediaStore.EXTRA_OUTPUT, fileUri); startActivityForResult(takePictureIntent, TAKE_PIC_ACTIVITY_REQUEST_CODE); } catch (Exception ex) { Toast.makeText(this, "Couldn't take picture", Toast.LENGTH_LONG).show(); } }

units.rawText: private void startCameraIntent(String name) { try { String fileName = MontageConstants.APP_DATA_FOLDER + "/"+ name + "/"+ new Date().getTime() + ".jpg"; Uri fileUri = Uri.fromFile(new File(fileName)); Intent takePictureIntent = new Intent(MediaStore.ACTION_IMAGE_CAPTURE); takePictureIntent.putExtra(MediaStore.EXTRA_OUTPUT, fileUri); startActivityForResult(takePictureIntent, TAKE_PIC_ACTIVITY_REQUEST_CODE); } catch (Exception ex) { Toast.makeText(this, "Couldn't take picture", Toast.LENGTH_LONG).show(); } }

node.contents: Thanks to Navjot Singh - I found the information that I needed at an answer he posted: How to rotate android device camera preview(libgdx). Effectively, you can read Exif tags in a stored JPEG file with the class ExifInterface. Since I was storing my pictures to file before manipulating them, I simply inserted the file path, got the orientation, and rotated/adjusted correspondingly.

astNode.text: Thanks to Navjot Singh - I found the information that I needed at an answer he posted: How to rotate android device camera preview(libgdx). Effectively, you can read Exif tags in a stored JPEG file with the class ExifInterface. Since I was storing my pictures to file before manipulating them, I simply inserted the file path, got the orientation, and rotated/adjusted correspondingly.

elements.contents: ExifInterface ei = new ExifInterface(fileName); orientation = ei.getAttributeInt(ExifInterface.TAG_ORIENTATION, ExifInterface.ORIENTATION_NORMAL);

units.rawText: ExifInterface ei = new ExifInterface(fileName); orientation = ei.getAttributeInt(ExifInterface.TAG_ORIENTATION, ExifInterface.ORIENTATION_NORMAL);
